message.content:
<<<api>>>: Hibernate
<<<code>>>: You can achieve this by using the @OneToMany annotation with the @OrderBy annotation and setting the maxResults property in the Hibernate query.
@Entity
public class Person {
    @Id
    @GeneratedValue
    private Long id;
    
    @OneToMany(cascade = CascadeType.ALL, fetch = FetchType.EAGER)
    @OrderBy("timestamp DESC")
    @JoinColumn(name = "PERSON_ID")
    @org.hibernate.annotations.Limit(maxResults = 5)
    private List<Activity> activities;
    
    // other setters, getters, etc.
}
<<<explanation>>>: By adding the @org.hibernate.annotations.Limit(maxResults = 5) annotation to the activities field, Hibernate will automatically limit the size of the collection to 5 during any fetch from the database. This will ensure that only the 5 latest activities are retrieved. Additionally, the @OrderBy("timestamp DESC") annotation ensures that the activities are ordered by timestamp in descending order, so the latest activities will be at the top.
